text: it is
it still allows for “what are you looking for” which has similar effects

<@U0DCXC37U>: i think that the issue is that women are socialized to behave a certain way, and sometimes we just take that for granted/internalize it to the point where we don’t even realize what we are doing. it’s also a problem of self perpetuation, where you behave in a non-assertive manner and then people take that to mean you are not in a position of authority

it’s true that these behaviors aren’t unique to men or women specifically, and that they are certainly expected and useful in specific scenarios, but i think it’s more important still to cultivate expectations that women are assertive and strong, especially with external communications
because as many awesome strong women (and people) we have working here, if we change our behaviors when interacting with clients it does us and the entire tech community a disservice
<http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/diversity-advocates-are-dumbfounded-saatchi-chairman-claims-gender-bias-over-172736>

attachments.title: Diversity Advocates Are Dumbfounded as Saatchi Chairman Claims Gender Bias Is 'Over'
attachments.text: Depressing. Damaging. Nonsense. Dead wrong. These are just a few of the many terms beieing used to describe Saatchi & Saatchi chairman Kevin Roberts' recent comments on women in advertising, and the chorus of angry voices is likely to continue growing.
attachments.fallback: AdWeek: Diversity Advocates Are Dumbfounded as Saatchi Chairman Claims Gender Bias Is 'Over'

text: "Roberts defended the lack of women in high-level roles by essentially saying that women are often happier in lower-level positions because they lack the "vertical ambition" of men. "
I was happy to see he left/was kicked out of Saatchi today.
i want to set the world on fire
>"My miscommunication on a number of points has caused upset and offense, and for this I am sorry.
“i’m sorry you were offended"
:fire:
the whole apology is like that
> "I have inadvertently embarrassed Saatchi & Saatchi and Publicis
>"I have expressed my regret and apology to the companies for the furor my remarks and language stimulated

going back to the assertive woman comms thing - I think there is a time for BOTH types of communications. Assertive is good, when warranted. And soft language is good, when warranted. Regardless of gender. But I TOTALLY agree that the problem is when we behave in an inappropriate way because we are socialized to behave that way.  Again, regardless of gender. :slightly_smiling_face: :slightly_smiling_face: :slightly_smiling_face:

<http://bigthink.com/videos/john-cleese-on-political-correctness>

attachments.title: We Can't Have Comedy and Be Politically Correct at the Same Time
attachments.text: The essence of comedy is being critical, says John Cleese, and that means causing offense sometimes. But we shouldn't protect everyone from experiencing negative emotions by enforcing political correctness.
attachments.fallback: Big Think: We Can't Have Comedy and Be Politically Correct at the Same Time

text: important food for thought.
I wholeheartedly disagree with Mr Cleese there
John Cleese is kind of a big jerk from what I've heard :confused:
(i suggest you watch, if you haven’t already!)

or at least, there is an implicit extension in the comedy world from “don’t say things that are offensive” to “well if everyone will get offended at anything, I might as well be allowed to be offensive"
super sensitivity and PC aren’t  necessarily the same thing

One of my favorite comedians is Amy Schumer (if you haven’t seen her show, Inside Amy Schumer, it’s pretty incredible) because she uses extreme satire. And yeah, you could easily get offended by a lot of the things she is saying. But for example her sketch about a woman president is hilarious because it’s actually what some people are worried about with a woman president and it’s just downright ridiculous… <http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/05/12/amy-schumer-shows-what-hillary-clinton-can-expect-as-first-female-president.html>

attachments.title: Amy Schumer Shows What Hillary Clinton Can Expect as First Female President
attachments.text: On her Comedy Central show this week, Hillary Clinton supporter Amy Schumer embodied everyone’s biggest irrational fears about the first female president.
attachments.fallback: The Daily Beast: Amy Schumer Shows What Hillary Clinton Can Expect as First Female President

text: <!channel>: Apologies I didn’t get this sent out yesterday, but to recap our diversity meeting yesterday… We mostly discussed different ways to follow up on the workshop during All Hands & our new event series - Food: Celebration of Diversity! <@U13GPDA1F> will also be reaching out to the Q Center to see if they have any workshops/speakers/etc that Uncorked could benefit from. I’ll send out the anonymous survey to collect feedback on our workshop along with a sign up sheet for Food: Celebration of Diversity!
<@U02613K0X|jenny> has left the channel

One thing I would like to define is our approach to designing for accessibility. We’re having some accessibility convos around Compass presently and I think that we should a) have a perspective / stance on it as a company and b) educate everyone about what it means/how to make something accessible

I think there are a lot of facets to that, not just on accessibility but also for diversity and inclusion, and how we take our principles and advise our clients on how to build inclusive and accessible products
Agreed. There are plenty of products that don’t consider accessibility or diversity. I’m disappointed to let accessibility take a back seat to designing for the majority.
i mentioned in compass, but i did some of this stuff when building for 503(c)s and am happy to nerd out about screen readers and cognitive disabilities and the like

we’ve been chatting about potential speakers/trainings/discussions to include - i think this is a great one if someone felt like they were knowledgable enough to speak to in a lunch + learn or similar
or if not, we can seek out someone from the outside
id love to know more / be able to speak to this better with clients
i was chatting with charles as well.  i did lots of accessibility work for the Met App a few years bck.  happy to help share what I learned and some contacts that were brought in
that would be aweeesssommmeeeeeee
We do a little bit for Live Case, but it’s a very small checklist. Would really like to do more from the tech side
I’d love that <@U0ML49XU0>

I don’t know what topics you would cover, but I think it would be really helpful to touch on accessibility best practices, plus speak to humanizing people with different vision limitations, and the benefits accessible designs have on the overall design quality.
<http://www.accessibletech.org/access_articles/webinfo/accessibleWebBenefit.php>
yeah, there’s vision, auditory, physical, cognitive disabilities that are easy to design yourself over
i will try and pull together some resources
thanks <@U06DFL7BP>
yesss! love this. we’ll make something happen
I would love for more attention to be put on accessibility in our overall process. I can attest that it’s historically been very difficult to get accessibility concerns taken seriously.
<@U026E0ZNR> do you feel that resistance was internal, or from clients?
both
or internal, because we assume it will be from clients :slightly_smiling_face:
same, I see it in both places. I did years of work with a client who did large digital installations. I was never successful in getting wheelchair accessibility or height considered.

i’m always throwing wrenches in design work, playing devil’s advocate, and trying to get hard questions to be answered, accessibility being one of the areas I always try touching on. usually it’s "not within scope” or maybe there’s just a lack of understanding around how important it actually is
one designer actually told me they wouldn’t have to worry about people with disabilities since most of the visitors would be rich
i think i brought it up concerning accessibility around motion design on the compass app lifetimes ago when this was a different product
i just know that usually it’s “not a big deal"
i think the OMSI project is the only one (that I was involved with) where we did a true accessibility sweep, but it was client requested
I hope as a company we can aim to be thoughtful and considerate of accessibility as the default.

sounds like theres actually a lot of people here that have experiences / knowledge to share - what do you guys think about having a round table convo about this to start with? (also this means needing a volunteer to lead the change - i dont feel equipped but would love to see this happen)
(or facilitate the convo)
<@U0HP6TFNX> i sort of think that depends on this group of people (diversity committee) and how we recommend this stuff for the team at large
i’d love to be there Lynsey, not sure about leading anything though
I’d agree it’s hard case to push when the project is going fast & furious.
<@U13GPDA1F>: panel or roundtable or just a jam session is a good idea
maybe just a forum with people asking squestions, sharing ideas and experience?  see what happens from therE?/
i think it may be different if the considerations were made at the beginning of the project rather than the end <@U0J6TE0CA>
^ True
yeah im in! if we find we’ve maxed out our knowledge than we can look to other resources for info/advisement
ill work with <@U0HS41J3Y> to get something on the calendar
thanks Lynsey!
thank you all!
ha
lol
too late ;)
